Welcome to Picka’s documentation!¶

Contents:

Picka is a data generation and randomization module which aims to increase coverage by increasing the amount of tests you _dont_ have to write by hand. By: Anthony Long

picka.english.age(min='', max='')[source]¶

Returns a random age, from a range.

Parameters :
min: (integer)

The lowest integer to use in the range

max: (integer)

The highest integer to use in the range

If min and max are empty, 1 and 100 will be used.

picka.english.apartment_number()[source]¶

Returns an apartment type, with a number.

There are many different types which could be returned. If you are looking for a specific format, you might be interested in using string formatting instead.

picka.english.business_title(abbreviated=False)[source]¶
Summary :

This will produce a random business title.
Parameters :
abbreviated: (boolean)

Do you want abbreviated titles?

This function will return business titles. They are generic business titles.

picka.english.calling_code_with_country(formatting='')[source]¶
Summary :Returns a country, with a calling code as a single string. If a format is passed in,

a 2 item object of your choosing will be returned. For example, if you pass in: calling_code_with_country(list), we will return a list of 2 items.

picka.english.city()[source]¶

This function will produce a city. ie - city() = ‘Brooklyn’.

picka.english.city_with_state()[source]¶

This function produces a city with a state. ie - city_with_state() = ‘New York, NY’

picka.english.country()[source]¶

This function will return a random country.

picka.english.cvv(i)[source]¶
Summary:Returns a cvv, based on the length you provide.

Usage: picka.cvv(3) or picka.cvv(4)

picka.english.email(length=8, domain='@example.com')[source]¶
Summary :Created a randomized email.
Usage :picka.email(length=8, domain='@antlong.com‘) >>> 'aijf39ss@antlong.com‘
picka.english.fax_number()[source]¶
Summary :Returns a fax (phone) number.
Usage :picka.fax_number() >>> 755-463-6544
picka.english.female_name()[source]¶
Summary :Returns a random female name.
Usage :picka.female_name() >>> ‘Christy’
picka.english.gender()[source]¶

Returns a random gender.

picka.english.hyphenated_last_name()[source]¶

This function will pick 2 random last names and hyphenate them. ie - hyphenated_last_name() = ‘Perry-Jenkins’

picka.english.initial()[source]¶

This function will return a capitalized letter with a ‘.’ ie - A.

picka.english.language()[source]¶

Picks a random language.

picka.english.last_name()[source]¶

This function will return a last name from a list. ie - last_name() = ‘Smith’.

picka.english.male_full_name_w_middle_initial()[source]¶

Returns name, middile initial and last name.

picka.english.male_middle_name()[source]¶

Picks a middle name from a list of male names.

picka.english.male_name()[source]¶

This function will return a male first name.

picka.english.month()[source]¶

Selects a month for you.

picka.english.month_and_day()[source]¶

Selects and month and day for you. There is logic to handle the days in the month correctly.

picka.english.month_and_day_and_year(start=1900, end=2010)[source]¶

Selects a monday, day and year for you. Logic built in to handle day in month. To change month do (a, b). b has +1 so the last year in your range can be selected. Default is 1900, 2010.

picka.english.name()[source]¶

Picks a random name. Could be male, could be female.

picka.english.number(x, y)[source]¶

This function will produce a random number with as many characters as you wish.

picka.english.password_alphabetical(i)[source]¶

This function will return a randomized password consisting of letters.

picka.english.password_alphanumeric(i)[source]¶

This function will return an alphanumeric password.

picka.english.password_numerical(i)[source]¶

This function will return a random password consisting of numbers.

picka.english.phone_number()[source]¶

This function will produce a phone number randomnly, with ‘-‘s.

picka.english.postal_code()[source]¶

This function will pick a zipcode randomnly from a list. ie - zipcode() = ‘11221’.

picka.english.random_string(i)[source]¶

This will allow you to enter an integer, and create ‘i’ amount of characters. ie: random_string(7) = DsEIzCd

picka.english.salutation()[source]¶

This function will return a ‘Mr.’ or ‘Mrs.’

picka.english.screename(service='')[source]¶

Makes screenames for the service you pick. The screenames conform to their rules, such as aol screenames are 3-16 in length with @aol.com on the end. Options include: nil, aol, aim, skype, google

picka.english.set_of_initials(i=3)[source]¶

Returns initials with period seperators.

picka.english.social_security_number()[source]¶

This function will produce a Mock Social Security Number. ie - social_security_number() = ‘112-32-3322’

picka.english.special_characters(i)[source]¶

This function will pick x amount of special chars from the list below. ie - picka.special_characters() = ‘@%^$’.

picka.english.state_abbreviated()[source]¶

This function produces just a state abbreviation. ie - state_abbreviated() = ‘NY’

picka.english.street_address()[source]¶

This function will produce a complete street address.

picka.english.street_name()[source]¶

This function will create a street name from either a male or female name, plus a street type.

picka.english.street_type()[source]¶

This function will return a random street type.

picka.english.suffix()[source]¶

This returns a suffix from a small list.

picka.english.timestamp(style=False)[source]¶

This is a convenience function for creating timestamps. Default when empty, is “12:28:59PM 07/20/10” or “%H:%M:%S%p %D”. To change this, pass in your format as an arg.

picka.english.timezone_offset()[source]¶

This function will select the value of a timezone offsets, such as GMT, GMT+4, etc.

picka.english.timezone_offset_country()[source]¶

This function will select the country part of a timezone.

picka.english.trash(function)[source]¶
Summary :This method takes a function you pass in, and joins the output with random punctuation.
Date :Tue Feb 22 15:31:12 EST 2011.
Usage :picka.trash(picka.name) >>> ‘D#o}y>l~e^’
picka.english.url(i, extension='.com')[source]¶

This function will create a website url, with a default of .com To use another extension, do picka.url(10, ”.net”)
